bill_title: to temporarily authorize school districts to extend school days to make up time lost because of inclement weather and to declare an emergency.

bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to temporarily authorize school districts to extend school days to make up time lost because of inclement weather and to declare an emergency. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. The provisions of § 13-26-5 notwithstanding, any school district during the 1997 spring semester may extend the length of one or more school days for purposes of making up school days or partial school days during which school was not in session because of inclement weather. Each forty-five minute increment of time that school is in session during a day beyond the five and one-half hour school day as defined in § 13-26-1 constitutes one-eighth of a make- up day. Once a school district has completed the equivalent of ten weather-related make-up days, regardless of whether the make-up days were held separately or as the result of time accumulated through the extension of school days as provided in this Act, the school district may no longer use extended school days for make-up purposes. Section 2. Whereas, this Act is necessary for the support of the state government and its existing public institutions, an emergency is hereby declared to exist, and this Act shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval. Section 3. This Act is repealed on July 1, 1997. 750 copies of this document were printed by the South Dakota Legislative Research Council at a cost of $.015 per page. . Insertions into existing statutes are indicated by underscores. Deletions from existing statutes are indicated by overstrikes.

FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to temporarily authorize school districts to extend school days to make up time lost because of inclement weather and to declare an emergency. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. The provisions of § 13-26-5 notwithstanding, any school district during the 1997 spring semester may extend the length of one or more school days for purposes of making up school days or partial school days during which school was not in session because of inclement weather. Each forty-five minute increment of time that school is in session during a day beyond the five and one-half hour school day as defined in § 13-26-1 constitutes one-eighth of a make- up day. Upon the effective date of this Act, any forty-five minute increment of time that a school spends in session during a day beyond the five and one-half hour school day as defined in § 13-26-1 may apply toward a make-up day. Once a school district has completed the equivalent of ten weather-related make-up days, regardless of whether the make-up days were held separately or as the result of time accumulated through the extension of school days as provided in this Act, the school district may no longer use extended school days for make-up purposes. Section 2. Whereas, this Act is necessary for the support of the state government and its existing public institutions, an emergency is hereby declared to exist, and this Act shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval. Section 3. This Act is repealed on July 1, 1997. BILL HISTORY 1/31/97 First read in Senate and referred to Education.
